sentences: Charles Singleton, known by his stage name Ducko McFli, is an American record producer, DJ, and songwriter based in Atlanta, Georgia.
section: N/A

sentences: He initially gained recognition in 2014 for his production work on Drake's "Draft Day".
section: N/A

sentences: He has since gone on to produce tracks for numerous notable artists including Lil Yachty, 2 Chainz, Khalid, and Joey Purp, among others.
section: N/A

sentences: He is currently signed to Same Plate Entertainment, a joint venture label with Sony Music, and he was also a member of Mike WiLL Made-It's Ear Drummers label.
section: N/A
== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Charles Singleton was born and raised in Nashville, Tennessee.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He began participating in informal rap battles while in high school.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: This led to him rapping over tracks and eventually producing his own beats.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: In 2010, he began using the Ducko McFli stage name and partnered with fellow Nashville producer Syk Sense to compete in local beat battles.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: The two competed and placed second in the Soundtrack Beat Battle that year.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: This led to them forming a working relationship with notable producer, Boi-1da, who was one of the judges of the competition.
section: == Early life ==
== Career ==

sentences: Career ==
section: == Career ==
== Career == | === 2011–2013: Early rap mixtapes and production work ===

sentences: 2011–2013: Early rap mixtapes and production work
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Early rap mixtapes and production work ===
== Career == | === 2011–2013: Early rap mixtapes and production work ===

sentences: In 2011, Ducko McFli released the mixtape, King Duck, on which McFli himself was the featured rapper.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Early rap mixtapes and production work ===

sentences: He also released numerous collaborations with artists as a producer including, Molotov (with OpenMic) N.O.B.O.T.S. (with Chancellor Warhol), and Chicago: Lake Shore Drive (with MC Drupy Fli).
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Early rap mixtapes and production work ===

sentences: In 2012, he traveled on Drake's Club Paradise Tour, serving in a behind-the-scenes role as French Montana's photographer and videographer.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Early rap mixtapes and production work ===

sentences: After returning to Nashville from the tour, McFli released another album entitled The Return of the Real.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Early rap mixtapes and production work ===

sentences: In November 2012, he released a collaboration with Dee Goodz called "We Wit It".
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Early rap mixtapes and production work ===

sentences: In January 2013, McFli released the track "N.I.Y.S." featuring Trinidad James.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Early rap mixtapes and production work ===

sentences: The following month, the music video for his song, "Cruising", was premiered on Vibe.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Early rap mixtapes and production work ===

sentences: That song would also reach number 3 on Hype Machine.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Early rap mixtapes and production work ===

sentences: Both songs were featured on McFli's project, Racthet Life, Sophisticated Dreams.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Early rap mixtapes and production work ===

sentences: In June 2013, he released another project in the EP, SykDuck, which was produced entirely by Syk Sense.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Early rap mixtapes and production work ===
== Career == | === 2013–2016: Move to Atlanta, "Draft Day", and increased production ===

sentences: 2013–2016: Move to Atlanta, "Draft Day", and increased production ===
section: == Career == | === 2013–2016: Move to Atlanta, "Draft Day", and increased production ===

sentences: In late 2013, McFli opted to leave Nashville and move to Atlanta where he planned to focus more on producing songs.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2016: Move to Atlanta, "Draft Day", and increased production ===

sentences: He spent six months in the city before landing a production placement on Drake's "Draft Day" alongside Syk Sense.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2016: Move to Atlanta, "Draft Day", and increased production ===

sentences: The song sampled Lauryn Hill's "Doo Wop (That Thing)".
section: == Career == | === 2013–2016: Move to Atlanta, "Draft Day", and increased production ===

sentences: He also began producing tracks as part of a collective known as "The Fam" consisting of himself, Syk Sense, and Atlanta producer, DJ FU.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2016: Move to Atlanta, "Draft Day", and increased production ===

sentences: Additionally, McFli was signed to Mike WiLL Made-It's Ear Drummers record label in 2014.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2016: Move to Atlanta, "Draft Day", and increased production ===

sentences: Because of his increased profile, McFli began earning further placements with artists like Fredo Santana ("Stay Da Same" featuring Lil Reese), ASAP Ferg ("This Side" featuring YG), OG Maco ("Fuckemx3" featuring Migos), and Audio Push ("Heavy" featuring OG Maco).
section: == Career == | === 2013–2016: Move to Atlanta, "Draft Day", and increased production ===

sentences: Complex also listed McFli as one of "10 producers to watch for in 2015".
section: == Career == | === 2013–2016: Move to Atlanta, "Draft Day", and increased production ===

sentences: That year, he continued producing tracks, including those for acts like EarthGang ("Momma Told Me") and Mike Floss ("Dopeboy Dreaming").
section: == Career == | === 2013–2016: Move to Atlanta, "Draft Day", and increased production ===

sentences: In February 2015, he released the track "I'm Serious" featuring Problem, Snootie Wild, and Reese.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2016: Move to Atlanta, "Draft Day", and increased production ===

sentences: He followed that with the release of a collaborative EP, Dreams, with Jace of Two-9.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2016: Move to Atlanta, "Draft Day", and increased production ===

sentences: He also released a mixtape called Lowlife in August 2015 with guest appearances from Jace, OG Maco, Audio Push, Problem, and others.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2016: Move to Atlanta, "Draft Day", and increased production ===

sentences: In 2016, he continued earning prominent placements including those with Lil Yachty ("Not My Bro"), Joey Purp ("Money & Bitches" featuring Mick Jenkins), and Khalid ("Reasons").
section: == Career == | === 2013–2016: Move to Atlanta, "Draft Day", and increased production ===

sentences: He also released another EP in November 2016 called The Lost Beauxs.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2016: Move to Atlanta, "Draft Day", and increased production ===
== Career == | === 2017–present: Further production work and signing to Same Plate ===

sentences: 2017–present: Further production work and signing to Same Plate =
section: == Career == | === 2017–present: Further production work and signing to Same Plate ===
== Career == | === 2017–present: Further production work and signing to Same Plate ===

sentences: In 2017, McFli produced two tracks ("Saturday Night" and "Poor Fool" featuring Swae Lee) off of the 2 Chainz mixtape Pretty Girls Like Trap Music and one ("Big God") off of Mike WiLL Made-It's Ransom 2 project.
section: == Career == | === 2017–present: Further production work and signing to Same Plate ===

sentences: In April of that year, he released a remix that combined 21 Savage's "No Heart" and Kanye West's "Heartless".
section: == Career == | === 2017–present: Further production work and signing to Same Plate ===

sentences: That same month, he released a second collaborative EP with Jace entitled Dreams 2.
section: == Career == | === 2017–present: Further production work and signing to Same Plate ===

sentences: In June 2018, it was announced that McFli was among the inaugural roster of Same Plate Entertainment, a joint venture label with Sony Music.
section: == Career == | === 2017–present: Further production work and signing to Same Plate ===

sentences: That year, he produced several songs including Skooly's "Dope Fiend" and Mike Floss's "Background Check".
section: == Career == | === 2017–present: Further production work and signing to Same Plate ===

sentences: In January 2019, he was among over 100 invitees to join J. Cole for his Revenge of the Dreamers III recording sessions.
section: == Career == | === 2017–present: Further production work and signing to Same Plate ===
